connected_components.details: This is an external capacitor. For general use, a 10 μF capacitor is recommended. For applications requiring high crest factor performance, a 0.1 μF capacitor can be used in conjunction with the CAVG capacitor. If converting to an average rectified value, a 470 pF capacitor is used. The capacitor style is important; surface mount tantalums are recommended for general use. For input amplitudes less than 1 mV, low dc leakage capacitors like film or X8L MLCs are best. Avoid electrolytic capacitors, or X7R or lower grade ceramics.

implementation.connectivity: Connect an external capacitor to the CAVG pin. The other end of the capacitor should be connected to ground. The value of this capacitor depends on the desired accuracy and frequency range.
implementation.detailed_description: The CAVG pin is a connection for an external averaging capacitor. This capacitor is used in the rms-to-dc conversion process to average the squared input voltage over several input waveform periods. The value of this capacitor directly impacts the rms conversion accuracy and the resultant ripple at the output.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of the CAVG pin is to connect to an external averaging capacitor (CAVG).  In a different mode, disconnecting the CAVG capacitor defaults the computed result to an average-value, but a minimum of 470pF capacitance is still required for stability.  If the intention is to convert to an average rectified value instead of RMS, the value of CAVG is reduced to 470 pF.
implementation.precautions: The value of the CAVG capacitor is critical for RMS accuracy. Ensure the capacitor value is appropriate for the lowest frequency of interest. If the output is intended to be an average rectified value, the CAVG capacitor value must be reduced to 470 pF. A minimum of 470 pF is required for stability even when aiming for average-value output. Ensure proper capacitor style is used to maintain accuracy, especially at low input levels or high temperatures.

connected_components.description: This capacitor is used for post-conversion filtering to reduce output ripple. Recommended values, as per the datasheet, range from 0.33 μF to 3.3 μF for typical ripple reduction. The specific value depends on the desired filtering characteristics. In Figure 27, it is shown connected between CCF and OUT.

implementation.connectivity: The CCF pin should be connected to one side of a capacitor (CLPF). The other side of the capacitor should be connected to the OUT pin (Pin 9) for a simple single-pole filter, or to the OBUFOUT pin (Pin 14) if the output buffer is used in a filtering configuration. For a dual-pole filter, it would be connected as per the Sallen-Key filter configuration shown in Figure 36.
implementation.detailed_description: The CCF pin is a connection point for a capacitor that is used in conjunction with the averaging capacitor (CAVG) to reduce residual ripple in the output signal after the RMS conversion. This capacitor is part of a post-conversion filter, often a single-pole filter, designed to smooth out the output waveform without affecting the accuracy of the RMS conversion itself.
implementation.functionality: The CCF pin's primary function is to connect to a capacitor (CLPF) that acts as a low-pass filter to reduce output ripple. The value of this capacitor, in conjunction with the internal 16 kΩ output resistor, determines the cutoff frequency of the filter. In some configurations, it can also be part of a two-pole Sallen-Key filter.
implementation.precautions: While the CLPF capacitor (connected to CCF) reduces ripple, it does not affect the RMS conversion accuracy. The value of the averaging capacitor (CAVG) is what primarily determines the RMS error. Ensure that the capacitor chosen for CCF is non-polarized. If using the output buffer for filtering, ensure proper connection to the OBUFOUT pin.

DNC.description: Do Not Connect. Used for factory test.

implementation.connectivity: This pin should not be connected to any external circuitry. It is recommended to leave it floating or unconnected in the schematic.
implementation.detailed_description: The DNC (Do Not Connect) pin is designated for factory testing purposes and is not intended for use in general circuit designs. It does not have a specified function for the end-user in typical applications.
implementation.functionality: This pin is reserved for internal factory testing and does not have a user-accessible functionality.
implementation.precautions: It is crucial not to connect any external components or signals to the DNC pin. Connecting to this pin could interfere with internal testing procedures or potentially lead to unexpected behavior or damage to the device, although its primary purpose is to be left unconnected.

DNC.name: DNC

connected_components.description: An optional resistor can be connected to this pin. If aiming for a gain of 2x, this pin is connected to ground (which can be thought of as a 0 Ohm connection). To achieve gains greater than 2x, an external resistor is connected between this pin and the IBUFIN- pin. The datasheet mentions that for a gain of 101x, a 100 Ohm resistor is used.
Connecting this pin to ground sets the input buffer gain to 2x.

implementation.connectivity: To achieve a gain of 2x for the input buffer, this pin should be connected to ground. For higher gains, an external resistor can be connected from this pin to the inverting input of the buffer (IBUFIN-).
implementation.detailed_description: The IBUFGN pin is associated with the on-chip FET input buffer. It is described as an 'Optional 10 kΩ Precision Gain Resistor' in the pin function descriptions. The datasheet indicates that this pin is used for gain in the input buffer.
implementation.functionality: Yes, this pin's functionality is tied to its connection. If connected to ground, it enables a gain of 2x for the input buffer. It can also be used with an external resistor to achieve higher gains.
implementation.precautions: The datasheet states that the bandwidth of the input buffer diminishes at a rate of approximately one decade per 20 dB of gain. Therefore, when using external resistors to achieve higher gains, the bandwidth limitations should be considered. The input gate of the buffer should not be allowed to float high; a 10 MΩ resistor from mid-supply to IBUFIN+ is used for this purpose. When configuring for higher gains using IBUFGN, ensure the internal 10 kΩ resistor from OBUF_OUT to IBUFIN− is taken into account or removed as necessary.

IBUFIN+.description: FET Input Buffer Noninverting Input Pin.

implementation.connected_components: Typically connected to the output of the signal source.  If gain is required, resistors will be connected between IBUFOUT and IBUFIN-. A 10 MΩ resistor may be connected to IGND (Pin 11) for bias stabilization.
implementation.connectivity: Connect to the signal source that needs to be buffered before being presented to the RMS core.  If the FET input buffer is being used for gain, external resistors will be connected between IBUFOUT and IBUFIN- to set the gain.  In some configurations, to prevent the input gate from floating, a 10 MΩ resistor may be connected from this pin to the IGND pin (Pin 11).
implementation.detailed_description: This pin is the non-inverting input for the FET Input Buffer amplifier. This buffer is designed to provide a high impedance interface to the RMS-to-DC converter's input, preventing loading of the signal source. It is typically used to buffer the input signal before it is fed into the RMS core.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of IBUFIN+ is to serve as the non-inverting input to the internal FET input buffer amplifier.  In addition to this, the datasheet mentions a connection to IGND (Pin 11) via a 10 MΩ resistor to prevent the input gate from floating high, suggesting a role in bias stabilization when the buffer is active.
implementation.precautions: Ensure that if the input buffer's power supply (IBUFV+) is disconnected, the non-inverting input (IBUFIN+) is also disconnected from the core output (OUT) if it was previously connected.  When using a 10 MΩ resistor to IGND for bias stabilization, ensure it does not excessively load the signal source at very low frequencies.

IBUFIN+.name: IBUFIN+

IBUFIN\u2212.description: FET Input Buffer Inverting Input Pin.

connected_components.description: The output pin of the FET input buffer. Typically connected to IBUFIN− for unity gain or used with external resistors to set gain.
Used to set the gain of the FET input buffer. For example, a 100 kΩ resistor connected from IBUFIN− to ground can provide a gain of 2, while other values can be used for higher gains.
When the FET input buffer is not in use or for specific gain configurations, IBUFIN− may be connected to ground.

implementation.connectivity: In a schematic, IBUFIN− should be connected to the output of the FET input buffer (IBUFOUT) for unity gain. To achieve higher gains, an external resistor should be connected from IBUFIN− to ground or to a feedback resistor from IBUFOUT. For applications where the FET input buffer is not used, this pin should be disconnected or connected to ground to prevent floating.
implementation.detailed_description: This pin is the inverting input for the FET input buffer amplifier. This buffer is designed to provide a high input impedance interface for the AD8436's RMS core, minimizing signal attenuation when interfacing with external components like voltage dividers or current transformers.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of IBUFIN− is to serve as the inverting input to the internal FET input buffer. It can also be connected to the IBUFOUT pin for unity gain configuration of the buffer. Additionally, external resistors can be connected to this pin to set the gain of the input buffer.
precautions: If the FET input buffer is not used, ensure that IBUFIN− is not left floating, as it can lead to unpredictable behavior. Connect it to ground or ensure it is properly terminated.

When configuring for gain, ensure the appropriate external resistors are used and that the chosen configuration does not exceed the operational limits of the buffer amplifier, particularly regarding bandwidth reduction at higher gains.
For accurate low-level signal measurements, consider connecting a capacitor between IBUFOUT and the RMS pin to mitigate the impact of the input buffer's offset voltage.

IBUFIN\u2212.name: IBUFIN-

connected_components.description: The AC input to the RMS core. IBUFOUT is often connected directly to this pin.

A capacitor can be connected between IBUFOUT and the RMS pin to AC couple the signal and reduce the impact of the FET input buffer's offset voltage. The specific value depends on the application's frequency requirements and desired filtering.
For gain configurations greater than 2x, external resistors are connected to the IBUFIN- pin and potentially from IBUFOUT to IBUFIN- (or other points) to set the desired gain.

implementation.connectivity: In a typical configuration for the RMS core, IBUFOUT is connected to the RMS pin (AC Input to the RMS Core). If the FET input buffer is not used, this pin can be left unconnected. For applications where the FET input buffer's offset voltage is a concern, a capacitor can be connected between IBUFOUT and the RMS pin to AC couple the signal and mitigate this offset. The AD8436 evaluation board schematic shows a 10pF capacitor from IBUFOUT to RMS for internal component connections, and also demonstrates configurations with external components for gain and filtering.
implementation.detailed_description: The IBUFOUT pin is the output of the on-chip FET input buffer amplifier. This buffer is designed to drive the 8 kΩ V-to-I input resistor of the AD8436's RMS core. It provides a low-impedance output for the buffer stage.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of IBUFOUT is to provide the buffered input signal to the RMS core. It can also be used in conjunction with external components to form a filter or to transfer the buffer's offset voltage to the RMS core input. The FET input buffer itself can be configured for unity gain or a gain of 2x internally, with options for higher gains using external resistors.
precautions: If the FET input buffer is not used, IBUFOUT should be left unconnected.
When connecting IBUFOUT to the RMS pin with a capacitor for offset voltage cancellation, ensure the capacitor value is appropriate for the lowest operating frequency to avoid attenuating the signal.
When configuring the FET input buffer for gain, be mindful of the bandwidth limitations as gain increases.
If the output buffer supply pin (OBUFV+) is disconnected, ensure the noninverting input (OBUFIN+) is also disconnected from the core output (OUT) to prevent unintended behavior.

IBUFV+.description: Power Pin for the Input Buffer.

connected_components.description: Connect to the positive voltage supply rail (e.g., VCC) to power the input buffer amplifier. If the buffer is not used, this pin should be left floating.

implementation.connectivity: In a schematic, this pin should be connected to the positive power supply rail (VCC or equivalent) when the input buffer is intended to be used. If the input buffer is not used, this pin should be left unconnected.
implementation.detailed_description: IBUFV+ is the power pin for the Input Buffer amplifier.
implementation.functionality: This pin supplies power to the on-chip JFET input buffer amplifier. The buffer can be powered down by leaving this pin unconnected, which helps in reducing power consumption in applications where the input buffer is not needed.
precautions: If the input buffer is not used, ensure IBUFV+ is left unconnected to minimize power consumption.
When the input buffer is used, ensure it is connected to an appropriate positive supply voltage within the device's operating range.

IBUFV+.name: IBUFV+

connected_components.description: A capacitor (typically 0.1 μF to 4.7 μF) can be connected between IGND and ground. This capacitor helps to filter out common-mode noise, especially in single-supply applications. The value is often determined empirically.
This resistor is internally connected from IGND to the noninverting input of the FET input buffer (IBUFIN+). It prevents the input gate from floating when the buffer is powered.

implementation.connectivity: In dual-supply configurations, IGND should be connected to the analog ground. In single-supply configurations, IGND should be connected to a voltage divider that biases the input and output buffers to half the supply voltage (VCC/2).  An optional bypass capacitor can be connected from IGND to ground to suppress common-mode noise.
implementation.detailed_description: The IGND pin serves as the half-supply node for the AD8436. This means it is internally connected to the midpoint of the power supply rails when dual supplies are used, or it acts as a reference point for single-supply operation.  It provides a stable reference for the internal circuitry, including the input and output buffers.
implementation.functionality: The IGND pin's primary function is to act as the half-supply node. In single-supply operation, it is used to bias the internal circuitry at VCC/2.  It is also connected to the internal 10 MΩ centering resistor for the FET input buffer, helping to prevent the input gate from floating.
implementation.precautions: In single-supply operation, ensuring IGND is correctly biased to VCC/2 is crucial for the proper operation of the internal buffers. If the FET input buffer is used, the 10 MΩ resistor connected to IGND must be considered when selecting input capacitor values to avoid excessive attenuation at low frequencies.

implementation.connected_components: Typically connected to the OUT pin of the AD8436 core or the IBUFOUT pin of the input buffer. When used in a gain or filtering configuration, it may be connected to external resistors and capacitors as per the application circuit.
implementation.connectivity: In a typical configuration as a unity-gain follower, OBUFIN+ should be connected directly to the output of the RMS core (OUT pin) or the output of the input buffer (IBUFOUT pin). If the output buffer is configured for gain or filtering, OBUFIN+ will be connected to other components in that circuit.
implementation.detailed_description: The OBUFIN+ pin is the non-inverting input for the precision output buffer amplifier. This pin receives the output signal from the RMS core (or the input buffer, depending on configuration) and is used to amplify or buffer this signal before it is outputted.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of OBUFIN+ is to serve as the non-inverting input to the output buffer. It can also be used in conjunction with the inverting input (OBUFIN-) and external components to configure the output buffer as a filter or an inverter.
implementation.precautions: If the output buffer is not used and its supply pin (OBUFV+) is disconnected, OBUFIN+ should also be disconnected from the core output to prevent unexpected behavior. If the output buffer is used as part of a filter or for gain, ensure correct external component selection and connections as described in the datasheet.

connected_components.connection_details: Directly connected or through a 16 kΩ resistor. The 'OUT' pin (Pin 9 on RQ-20, Pin 10 on CP-20-8) is the voltage or current output of the RMS core.
connected_components.purpose: To feed the processed RMS signal into the output buffer.

connected_components.connection_details: Used to set gain and/or configure filters (e.g., Sallen-Key filter). For example, a 16 kΩ resistor may be used for feedback in a unity-gain configuration, or other values for different gains or filter characteristics.
connected_components.purpose: To define the behavior and characteristics of the output buffer amplifier.

connected_components.connection_details: Used in conjunction with resistors to form filters (e.g., Sallen-Key low-pass filter). The averaging capacitor (CAVG) and crest factor capacitor (CCF) are connected to other pins but influence the signal processed by the output buffer.
connected_components.purpose: To shape the frequency response of the output signal and reduce ripple.

implementation.connectivity: In a schematic, this pin is typically connected to the output of the RMS core (OUT pin) through a 16 kΩ resistor or directly if the output buffer is configured as a unity-gain follower. It can also be connected to the output of a filter or other signal conditioning circuits.
implementation.detailed_description: The OBUFIN− pin is the inverting input for the output buffer amplifier. This buffer is a precision amplifier optimized for high DC accuracy.
implementation.functionality: The primary function is to serve as the inverting input to the output buffer. It can be used in various configurations such as a unity-gain follower, a filter, or an inverting amplifier, depending on external component connections.
precautions: If the output buffer supply pin (OBUFV+) is disconnected to save power, the OBUFIN– pin (and the rest of the output buffer) must also be disconnected from the core output (OUT pin).
The output buffer has a laser-trimmed 16 kΩ resistor in series with this inverting input to offset any self-bias offset voltage. This should be considered when designing external feedback networks.
When configuring the output buffer as a filter, ensure appropriate capacitor and resistor values are chosen based on the desired cutoff frequency and filter type.

connected_components.description: The downstream circuitry that will utilize the converted RMS voltage.
Used for post-conversion filtering to reduce ripple. Connected from OBUFOUT to ground.
Used to configure the output buffer for gain or as part of a filter network. Connected between OBUFOUT and OBUFIN- or OBUFIN+.
Used in two-pole Sallen-Key filter configurations. Connected between OBUFOUT and other filter components.

implementation.connectivity: In a typical configuration, OBUFOUT is connected directly to the load or to the input of the next stage in the circuit. For basic operation as a unity-gain follower, it is often connected back to the inverting input of the output buffer (OBUFIN-). To reduce ripple, an external capacitor (CLPF) can be connected from OBUFOUT to ground (as shown in Figure 26). For a two-pole filter, it connects to a more complex filter network (Figure 36). In an inverting configuration, it connects to the output of the inverting network (Figure 37).
implementation.detailed_description: The OBUFOUT pin is the output of the precision output buffer amplifier. This buffer is designed for high DC accuracy and can drive low impedance loads. It is internally connected to a 16 kΩ resistor, which is part of the I-to-V conversion in the RMS core. The output buffer can be used as a unity gain follower, or it can be configured for gain or as a low-pass filter.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of OBUFOUT is to provide the final, buffered DC output voltage representing the RMS value of the input signal. It can also be configured with external components to act as a low-pass filter (single or two-pole) to reduce ripple, or to provide inversion of the DC output.
implementation.precautions: If the output buffer is not used, the OBUFOUT pin should not be left floating if the output buffer supply pin (OBUFV+) is disconnected. If the buffer supply is disconnected, the non-inverting input (OBUFIN+) should also be disconnected from the core output (OUT). The output buffer can drive loads down to 5 kΩ without significant error, and can sink up to 0.5 mA or source up to 15 mA.

OBUFV+.description: Power Pin for the Output Buffer.

implementation.connected_components: This pin connects directly to the positive supply rail (VCC). It can also be connected to a switch that controls power to the output buffer, as indicated in the evaluation board description where 'OBUF_VCC' switch controls this functionality.
implementation.connectivity: This pin should be connected to the positive supply rail (VCC) when the output buffer is to be used. If the output buffer is not used, this pin should be left unconnected. The datasheet notes that if the buffer supply pin (OBUFV+) is disconnected, the noninverting input of the buffer should also be disconnected from the core output (OUT).
implementation.detailed_description: The OBUFV+ pin is the positive supply pin for the output buffer amplifier. This allows the output buffer to be powered independently from the main RMS core, enabling power saving if the buffer is not required.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of this pin is to provide power to the output buffer amplifier. It can be connected to the positive supply rail (VCC) to enable the output buffer or left unconnected if the output buffer is not used, thereby saving power.
implementation.precautions: If the OBUFV+ pin is disconnected (i.e., the output buffer is powered down), the noninverting input of the output buffer (OBUFIN+) must also be disconnected from the core output (OUT pin) to prevent unexpected behavior or damage.

OBUFV+.name: OBUFV+

connected_components.description: The primary connection for the OGND pin. This ensures a stable reference voltage for all analog circuitry.
A small capacitor (e.g., 0.1 uF to 1 uF, ceramic) connected between OGND and the analog ground/VEE. This capacitor helps filter out high-frequency noise.

implementation.connectivity: In a schematic, the OGND pin should be connected directly to the circuit's analog ground plane or net. For optimal performance and to minimize noise, it is recommended to connect it to a dedicated analog ground rather than a mixed-signal or digital ground if separate grounds are available. A bypass capacitor from OGND to the negative supply (VEE) or a common ground is often used to further improve noise performance.
implementation.detailed_description: The OGND pin serves as the analog ground connection for the AD8436. It is the reference point for analog signals and internal circuitry within the device. Proper connection of OGND is crucial for maintaining signal integrity and accurate operation of the RMS-to-DC converter.
implementation.functionality: The OGND pin is dedicated to analog ground. It does not serve different functions based on connectivity. It should always be connected to the analog ground reference of the system.
precautions: Ensure that the OGND pin is connected to a clean analog ground. Connecting it to a noisy digital ground or power supply rail can significantly degrade performance.
In systems with separate analog and digital grounds, always connect OGND to the analog ground. The two grounds should ideally be connected at a single point, usually at the power supply.
For sensitive applications, consider using a star ground configuration with OGND as the central connection point for analog signals.
Refer to the 'Power Supply Recommendations' and 'Layout Considerations' sections of the datasheet for best practices regarding ground connections and bypass capacitor placement.

OUT.description: RMS Core Voltage or Current Output.

connected_components.description: The output buffer (connected via OBUFIN+) can be used to provide a voltage output with 0 Ω source impedance. An external averaging capacitor (CAVG) is typically connected to the CAVG pin, and an optional filter capacitor (CLPF) can be connected to the OUT pin for ripple reduction.
For current output applications, the OUT pin is connected to the load or the input of a current summing amplifier.
While not directly connected to OUT, the behavior of OUT is influenced by the averaging capacitor connected to the CAVG pin.
An optional filter capacitor can be connected from the OUT pin to ground to reduce output ripple.

implementation.connectivity: For a voltage output, the OUT pin should be connected to the input of the output buffer (OBUFIN+) or to the next stage of the circuit. If a current output is desired, the OUT pin should be connected directly to the load or the summing node of a current summing amplifier. If the output buffer is used, the OUT pin is connected to the OBUFIN+ pin.
implementation.detailed_description: The OUT pin serves as the voltage or current output of the RMS core. It can be configured as a voltage source in series with a 16 kΩ resistor, or if the connection to ground is left open, the output current can be directed to a subsequent circuit, such as a current summing amplifier. For a voltage output with a 0 Ω source impedance, the output buffer should be used.
implementation.functionality: The pin can function as either a voltage output (in series with 16 kΩ) or a current output, depending on the external circuit configuration. When used with the output buffer, it provides a voltage output with 0 Ω source impedance.
precautions: If the output buffer's power supply pin (OBUFV+) is disconnected, the noninverting input (OBUFIN+) must also be disconnected from the core output (OUT) to prevent the buffer from floating.
The OUT pin has a 16 kΩ internal resistor in series when configured as a voltage output. This should be considered in circuit design.
For current output applications, the precision of the output is dependent on the internal trimmed resistor, which can be bypassed for external calibration.
Ensure proper decoupling and filtering as described in the datasheet to manage ripple and maintain accuracy, especially in sensitive applications.

OUT.name: OUT

RMS.description: AC Input to the RMS Core.

connected_components.description: The AC signal to be measured.

A capacitor (e.g., 4.7 μF or 10 μF tantalum) connected in series with the signal source for AC coupling. This ensures that the input offset voltage of the AD8436 does not affect the measurement and helps achieve a near-zero output offset.

implementation.connectivity: In a schematic, this pin should be connected to the AC signal source. For AC-coupled operation, an input coupling capacitor is required in series with the signal source before connecting to the RMS pin. The datasheet suggests a coupling capacitor value similar to or half the value of the averaging capacitor (CAVG), for example, 4.7 μF or 10 μF if CAVG is 10 μF.
implementation.detailed_description: The RMS pin is the AC input to the core of the AD8436 True RMS to DC converter. This is where the AC waveform is applied for measurement.
implementation.functionality: The pin serves as the primary input for the RMS conversion process. It is intended for AC signals. The datasheet mentions that the input can be AC-coupled or DC-coupled, but AC-coupling is recommended to achieve near-zero output offset voltage.
precautions: If the RMS pin is DC-coupled, the input offset voltage of the AD8436 will be reflected in the output and may require calibration.
AC coupling is recommended for optimal performance (near-zero output offset).
The input impedance at this pin is 8 kΩ (as it connects to the internal voltage-to-current conversion resistor). Ensure the signal source can drive this impedance or use the input buffer.

RMS.name: RMS

implementation.connected_components: The SUM pin is typically connected to the 'OUT' pin of the AD8436 itself, which represents the voltage or current output of the RMS core. If the output buffer is utilized, the SUM pin would also be connected to the non-inverting input of the output buffer (OBUFIN+ pin).
implementation.connectivity: In a typical configuration, the SUM pin is connected to the output of the RMS core. If the output buffer is used, the SUM pin would be connected to the output of the RMS core (OUT pin) and then this signal would be fed into the input of the output buffer.
implementation.detailed_description: The SUM pin is the input to the summing amplifier. It is where the input signal, after being processed by the RMS core, is typically fed into the summing amplifier.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of the SUM pin is to receive the signal from the RMS core. It acts as an input node for an amplifier circuit. Depending on the desired output configuration (e.g., voltage output with zero source impedance), the signal from the SUM pin might be further processed by an output buffer.
implementation.precautions: The datasheet mentions that the SUM pin is an input to a summing amplifier. Care should be taken to ensure that the signal level fed to this pin is within the operational limits of the amplifier stage it connects to. The 'SUM' pin is part of the internal summing amplifier, which in turn can be connected to the output buffer. Ensure that the output of the RMS core is properly connected to this pin, and if the output buffer is used, that its input is correctly connected to the SUM pin.

VCC.description: Positive Supply Rail for the RMS Core.

connected_components.description: A capacitor is typically connected between the VCC pin and ground. This capacitor acts as a local energy reservoir and filters out high-frequency noise from the power supply, ensuring stable operation of the RMS core. The datasheet recommends a value of 10 µF for CAVG and 3.3 µF for CLPF for general applications, and bypass capacitors on the supply lines are standard practice for ICs. Specific bypass capacitor values for VCC are not explicitly stated in the provided sections but are generally in the range of 0.1 µF to 10 µF, placed close to the IC. The data sheet mentions 'An additional bypass capacitor can be helpful at Pin 11 (IGND) to suppress potential common-mode noise. The capacitor value is most likely determined empirically, but ranges between 0.1 µF and 4.7 µF.' This suggests that bypass capacitors are indeed important for power integrity.

connected_components.connection: Connected to the positive voltage output of the system's power supply.
connected_components.description: This is the main power source for the device, typically a regulated DC voltage. The AD8436 supports a wide power supply voltage range from ±2.4 V to ±18 V for dual supplies, or 4.8 V to 36 V for single supplies. The VCC pin is the positive terminal for these supplies.

implementation.connectivity: The VCC pin should be connected to the positive voltage supply rail of the system. This typically involves connecting it to the output of a voltage regulator or a stable DC power source. A bypass capacitor should be connected between VCC and ground close to the IC to ensure stable operation and filter out noise.
implementation.detailed_description: VCC is the positive supply rail for the RMS core of the AD8436. It provides the necessary power for the core circuitry to operate and perform its true RMS to DC conversion function.
implementation.functionality: The VCC pin serves as the primary positive power supply input for the internal RMS core. It dictates the operational voltage range for this critical section of the IC.
implementation.precautions: Ensure that the voltage applied to the VCC pin does not exceed the absolute maximum ratings specified in the datasheet (±18 V for dual supplies). Proper bypassing of the VCC pin with a capacitor placed close to the IC is crucial for preventing oscillations and ensuring stable operation, especially in noisy environments. The datasheet specifies the supply voltage range in the 'Specifications' table and 'Absolute Maximum Ratings' table. For dual supplies, VCC is the positive rail. For single supply operation, VCC is the main positive supply rail.

VCC.name: VCC

implementation.connected_components: Typically connected to the negative terminal of a power supply or to ground.
implementation.connectivity: For dual-supply operation, VEE should be connected to the negative voltage supply rail (e.g., -5V, -15V). For single-supply operation, VEE should be connected to ground (GND).
implementation.detailed_description: VEE is the negative supply rail for the AD8436. It provides the negative voltage necessary for the operation of the internal circuitry, including the RMS core and the output buffer. The datasheet specifies a wide range for the dual supply voltage, from ±2.4 V to ±18 V.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of the VEE pin is to serve as the negative power supply input for the AD8436. In single-supply operation, this pin is connected to ground. The datasheet also mentions that the negative rail of the input buffer is internally connected, so the VEE pin is the negative supply for the overall device.
implementation.precautions: Ensure that the voltage applied to VEE is within the specified absolute maximum ratings (±18 V) and operating range (±2.4 V to ±18 V for dual supply). In single-supply operation, connecting VEE to ground is crucial for correct operation. If the input buffer's positive supply pin (IBUFV+) is powered, and VEE is not connected to ground in single-supply mode, it could lead to improper biasing.
